item.title: ÊØîÂ∞î¬∑È©¨Ëµ´Ôºà Bill Maher Ôºâ‰∏é‰ºóËÆÆÂëòÊù∞Ê£Æ¬∑ÂÖãÂä≥Ôºà Jason Crow Ôºâ‰∫âËÆ∫È©¨ÂßÜËææÂ∞ºÔºà Mamdani ÔºâÊãÖ‰ªªÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂ∏ÇÈïøÁöÑÂèØËÉΩÊÄßÔºö ‚ÄúÊàë‰ª¨‰ªéÊú™ÊúâËøáÂ¶ÇÊ≠§ÊøÄËøõÁöÑ‰∫∫
item.description:
Comedian Bill Maher sparred Friday with one of his guests, Rep. Jason Crow, D-Colo., when the lawmaker dismissed criticism of New York City‚Äôs Democratic socialist mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani as a ‚Äúcontrived villain or boogeyman.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not contrived. He‚Äôs gonna be the mayor of New York,‚Äù Maher argued.

The late-night show host cited Mamdani‚Äôs ‚ÄúMarxist‚Äù positions, such as the ‚Äúabolition of private property,‚Äù after he declared that the Big Apple has ‚Äúnever had someone this radical.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of opposition [to Mamdani] because we‚Äôve never had someone this radical,‚Äù Maher warned. ‚ÄúSome of the things he says, you know he quotes Marxists, ‚Äòeach according to their need.‚Äô I mean, that‚Äôs straight up Communism.‚Äù

Meanwhile, Rep. Crow maintained that a ‚Äúboogeyman‚Äù like Mamdani comes around every election cycle for Republicans.

‚ÄúThey always try to create a villain is my point,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey always try to create some boogeyman or bogeywoman.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, these are quotes. I‚Äôm not creating anything, I‚Äôm quoting [Mamdani],‚Äù Maher debated.

The comedian‚Äôs second guest, columnist James Kirchick, did not hesitate to chime in about the criticism Mamdani has received from conservatives.¬†

‚ÄúEverything that the crazy far-right alleged about Obama ‚Äì wasn‚Äôt born in America, Islamist, socialist, antisemite, hates America, it‚Äôs all true about this guy [Mamdani],‚Äù Kirchick claimed.

Kirchick went on to describe what he finds the ‚Äúmost appalling‚Äù about Mamdani.

‚ÄúHe defends the expression ‚Äòglobalize the intifada,‚Äô which explicitly means ‚Äì and I don‚Äôt wanna hear anyone deny this ‚Äì it means kill Jews whenever and wherever you can find them,‚Äù Kirchick added.

The ‚ÄúSecret City‚Äù author hit both sides of the political aisle, comparing Democrats who are not refusing to endorse Mamdani to Republicans 10 years ago, who were ‚Äúletting Trump go on and on and they weren‚Äôt standing up to him.‚Äù

‚ÄúI feel with this guy we‚Äôre seeing the same sort of cowardice and spinelessness,‚Äù Kirchick asserted.¬†

In July, the New York Times reported that Mamdani told a group of business leaders he would not use the phrase ‚Äúglobalize the intifada,‚Äù and he would ‚Äúdiscourage‚Äù others from using it.

The American Pulse polling firm conducted a survey in July, in which it found that 30% of New York City voters support Mamdani‚Äôs refusal to condemn the phrase ‚Äúglobalize the intifada‚Äù and his backing of the anti-Israel boycott movement.
item.author: Fox News

item.title: ÂñúÂâßÊºîÂëòÈ©¨Áâπ¬∑ÈáåÂ§´Ôºà Matt Rife ÔºâË¥≠‰π∞‰∫ÜÊ¥õÊûó¬∑Ê≤É‰º¶Ôºà Lorraine Warren ÔºâÂú®Â∫∑Ê∂ÖÁãÑÊ†ºÂ∑ûÁöÑÂÆ∂ÂíåÂçöÁâ©È¶ÜËâæÂæ∑‚ÄîÊàê‰∏∫ÊÅ∂È≠î‚ÄúÂÆâÂ®úË¥ùÂ∞î‚ÄùÂ®ÉÂ®É
item.description:
Comedian Matt Rife‚Äôs new purchase is ha-ha-haunted.

Rife revealed Friday that he purchased the Connecticut home and occult museum of paranormal investigators Ed and Lorraine Warren, becoming the ‚Äúlegal guardian‚Äù of the famed Annabelle doll.

The stand-up comic, who bought the house alongside his pal and YouTube star Elton Castee, called the centuries-old farmhouse the ‚Äúmost important and prominent pieces of paranormal history in the world.‚Äù

‚ÄúEd and Lorraine Warren are who took demonology, ghost hunting and paranormal investigation and made it mainstream,‚Äù Rife told his TikTok followers.

The Monroe, Conn. home was once owned by the real-life couple who conducted over 3,000 paranormal investigations that inspired movies like ‚ÄúThe Conjuring‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Amityville Horror.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Conjuring films are my favorite scary movies of all time,‚Äù Rife shared. ‚ÄúSo I‚Äôm incredibly honored to have taken over one of the most prominent properties in paranormal history.‚Äù

Rife did not reveal how much he spent on his purchase.

Haunted relics from the Warrens‚Äô adventures remained on the property after their death including fragments of crashed Eastern Airlines Flight 401 and an organ that can play on its own.

The museum also houses Annabelle, the giant Raggedy Ann doll, which was kept locked in a case labeled ‚ÄúWarning: Positively Do Not Open.‚Äù

The doll is believed to have a ‚Äúdemonic‚Äù presence attached to it after it allegedly terrorized two roommates in the 1970s by mysteriously moving by itself, leaving creepy notes and it was accused of trying to strangle a friend sleeping in the apartment.

Most recently, it was part of the ‚ÄúDevils on the Run Tour,‚Äù hosted by paranormal investigator Dan Rivera, who died suddenly in his hotel room on July 13.

Rivera was traveling around the US with other members of the New England Society for Psychic Research to show off Annabelle as part of his tour.

The doll was not in the room when he died and state police claim ‚Äúnothing unusual or suspicious‚Äù was found at the scene.

Rivera‚Äôs cause of death has not yet been released.

The recent incident has not stopped Rife from leaning into his new ‚Äúhobby.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are the legal guardians and caretakers of all 750 haunted artifacts and items in the Warren museum including the Annabelle doll,‚Äù Rife said. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt legally own the items, but we are legal guardians and caretakers of the items for at least the next five years.‚Äù

The ‚ÄúWild ‚ÄòN Out‚Äù improviser plans to reopen the haunted doors for museum tours and overnight stays to ‚Äúlearn all the haunted history surrounding this amazing place.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is the most random hobby ever, but it‚Äôs so f‚Äîing cool, man. I should probably collect stamps or something,‚Äù Rife quipped. ‚ÄúMight be a little safer.‚Äù

The new owners will likely have to fix up the property‚Äôs fire-safety issues before they can share it, according to The Providence Journal.

‚ÄúStill can‚Äôt believe we‚Äôre the new owners‚Ä¶ Sitting on their porch now looking at all the photos of them at this house. We‚Äôre gonna make this the best paranormal investigation location on the planet,‚Äù co-owner Elton Castee commented under Rife‚Äôs announcement.

The home and museum were not open to the public in recent years after it was shut down in 2019 due to zoning issues.
item.author: Jacki Thrapp

item.title: Columbia SportswearÂú®ÊúÄÊñ∞ÁöÑÂ∏∏Êò•Ëó§Ê≥ïÂæãËØâËÆº‰∏≠Ëµ∑ËØâÂì•‰º¶ÊØî‰∫öÂ§ßÂ≠¶
item.description:
For decades, T-shirts, sweatshirts and other clothing under the Columbia Sportswear brand and clothing emblazoned with the Columbia University name coexisted more or less peacefully without confusion.

But now, the Portland-based outdoor retailer has sued the New York-based university over alleged trademark infringement and a breach of contract, among other charges.

It claims that the university‚Äôs merchandise looks too similar to what‚Äôs being sold at more than 800 retail locations including more than 150 of its branded stores as well as its website and third-party marketplaces.

In a lawsuit filed July 23 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon, Columbia Sportswear, whose roots date back to 1938, alleges that the university intentionally violated an agreement the parties signed on June 13, 2023.

That agreement dictated how the university could use the word ‚ÄúColumbia‚Äù on its own apparel.

As part of the pact, the university could feature ‚ÄúColumbia‚Äù on its merchandise provided that the name included a recognizable school insignia or its mascot, the word ‚Äúuniversity,‚Äù the name of the academic department or the founding year of the university ‚Äî 1754 ‚Äî or a combination.

But Columbia Sportswear alleges the university breached the agreement a little more than a year later, with the company noticing several garments without any of the school logos being sold at the Columbia University online store.

Many of the garments feature a bright blue color that is ‚Äúconfusingly similar‚Äù to the blue color that has long been associated with Columbia Sportswear, the suit alleged.

The lawsuit offered photos of some of the Columbia University items that say only Columbia.

‚ÄúThe likelihood of deception, confusion, and mistake engendered by the university‚Äôs misappropriation and misuse of the Columbia name is causing irreparable harm to the brand and goodwill symbolized by Columbia Sportswear‚Äôs registered mark Columbia and the reputation for quality it embodies,‚Äù the lawsuit alleged.

The lawsuit comes at a time when Columbia University has been threatened with the potential loss of billions of dollars in government support.

Last week,¬†Columbia University reached a deal¬†with the Trump administration to pay more than $220 million to the federal government to restore¬†federal research money¬†that was canceled in the name of combating antisemitism on campus.

Under the agreement, the Ivy League school will pay a $200 million settlement over three years, the university said.

Columbia Sportswear aims to stop all sales of clothing that violate the agreement, recall any products already sold and donate any remaining merchandise to charity.

Columbia Sportswear is also seeking three times the amount of actual damages determined by a jury.

Neither Columbia Sportswear or Columbia University couldn‚Äôt be immediately reached for comment.
item.author: Associated Press

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÂæãÂ∏àËÄÉËØïÊúüÈó¥ÔºåÊ≥ïÂæãÊØï‰∏öÁîüÂøÉËÑèÈ™§ÂÅú‚ÄîËÄÉËØï‰∏çÈó¥Êñ≠Âú∞ËøõË°åÔºöÊä•Âëä
item.description:
The test must go on.

A Fordham Law grad went into cardiac arrest while taking the bar exam Wednesday, but other aspiring lawyers were reportedly forced to shoulder on during the scary ordeal.

As school safety officials worked to revive the unidentified woman inside Hofstra University‚Äôs sports complex in Hempstead, Long Island, proctors didn‚Äôt immediately pause the second day of the New York State Bar Examination, according to Newsday and ABC 7, which spoke with test-takers.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a real person who could be dying right in front of us, and we‚Äôre still being expected to continue to finish our questions for this exam,‚Äù one law student told the newspaper.

The medical episode happened just before a lunch break, when the woman fell from her chair and went into medical distress inside the David S. Mack Sports and Exhibition Complex, a Hofstra spokesperson told The Post.

Public safety officers immediately provided CPR and other life-saving measures until paramedics reached the scene and rushed her to a local hospital. Her condition was not immediately known.

When test-takers returned from lunch, the scene was clear, and they didn‚Äôt hear about the unnerving moment again.

‚ÄúFrom a purely human standpoint, that‚Äôs another human being in distress. And that‚Äôs not something that you could just be flip to the back of your mind immediately ‚Äî at least for me,‚Äù the law student also told Newsday, which reported the pupil was also from Fordham Law.

But the state Board of Law Examiners, which administers the tests, defended the proctors‚Äô actions.

‚ÄúThis event occurred only a few minutes before the scheduled end of the exam session,‚Äù the board said in a statement to ABC 7. ‚ÄúOur staff came to the examinee‚Äôs aid as soon as they were alerted to the situation.‚Äù

But another student, Isaac, claimed to the outlet that there wasn‚Äôt enough urgency from the staff.

‚ÄúThe students around her were telling the proctors, ‚ÄòWhy are you refusing to seek assistance?'‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd she kept on saying, ‚ÄòShut up, and continue with the exam.'‚Äù

Some students near the medical emergency were in tears and moved their seats for arriving first responders, Newsday reported.

The Post could not reach the state board for comment Friday.

Applicants need to pass the state bar exam to practice law in New York.

Nicole Lefton, who is a Hofstra Law School instructor and head of academic support and bar exam preparation, told test-takers that services were available in the aftermath of the shocking incident.

‚ÄúWe understand that witnessing a medical incident during the Bar Exam today may have been distressing,‚Äù she wrote, per Newsday.

‚ÄúWhile we cannot share any medical details about the incident, we want to acknowledge the impact it may have had on you.‚Äù
item.author: David Propper

item.title: HochulÂ∞ÜMTAÂú∞Áã±Ëà¨ÁöÑÊúçÂä°Â¥©Ê∫ÉÂΩíÂíé‰∫é‚ÄúÁº∫‰πèÊäïËµÑ‚Äù ÔºåÂç≥‰ΩøËáÉËÇøÁöÑÂÖ¨ÂÖ±‰∫§ÈÄöÊú∫ÊûÑÂ∞ÜÁ•®‰ª∑ÊèêÈ´òÂà∞3ÁæéÂÖÉ
item.description:
Just throw more money at the problem!

Gov. Kathy Hochul on Friday blamed decades-long ‚Äúlack of investments‚Äù in subway infrastructure for hellish service meltdowns this week amid stifling heat and torrential downpours ‚Äî even as she directed MTA officials to conduct a ‚Äúpretty much full review‚Äù of the issues.

Hochul, standing alongside Metropolitan Transportation Authority honcho Janno Lieber, acknowledged the repeated failures had left straphangers running late or frustrated.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want any person to feel as if they aren‚Äôt getting first-rate service, so I‚Äôve directed Janno and his team to provide a pretty much full review of what occurred this week,‚Äù she said.

Power outages at the West Fourth Street station during the morning commute on both Tuesday and Thursday caused travel nightmares for thousands of subway-riders, some of whom vowed to jump turnstiles to steal back their lost time.

Hochul already appeared primed to point the finger at the ‚Äúlack of investments‚Äù in the subway system, despite the MTA raking ever-increasing billions of dollars over decades for infrastructure improvements, imposing a $9 congestion pricing toll and, this week, eyeing a fare increase to $3.

The governor even touted the MTA‚Äôs latest, record-breaking $68.4 billion capital plan for 2025-2029 as a step forward in fixing the infrastructure woes, specifically for electrical upgrades.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why we‚Äôre continuing the investments, $4 billion to upgrade the electrical system,‚Äù Hochul said during an unrelated press conference.

The MTA plans to spend the $4 billion on power and electricity components over the next five years, according to the capital plan.

This includes around $3 billion specifically for the system‚Äôs 224 substations and 317 circuit breaker houses.

But even after the upgrades planned for in the most recent capital plan are complete, the MTA estimates a little more than a quarter, 27%, of substations will still be in poor or marginal condition, per the plan.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm very annoyed,‚Äù Kate Whitman, a 26-year-old creative executive, said Friday, lamenting the proposed $3 fare.

The shoddy subway service this week forced Whitman to shell out $80 in Ubers heading to work in Brooklyn and back from her West Village home.

But she said she has been late to work multiple times because of poor subway service even before the troubles.

‚ÄúI know the system is severely outdated. It‚Äôs very obvious that it would be an extensive audit required, but, like, it‚Äôs very clear that the money isn‚Äôt being used very wisely at all.‚Äù

MTA officials have sounded alarm bells in recent years about the subway system‚Äôs decaying, often-century-old infrastructure.

The budget for the transit agency‚Äôs capital plan in 2000-2004 stood at just shy of $22 billion ‚Äî and has only increased for each subsequent five-year cycle, records show.

On-time performance during 2017 ‚Äî which featured the notorious ‚Äúsummer of hell‚Äù ‚Äî hit a dismal 63%, data shows.

Since then, on-time performance has improved significantly, hitting 89% in 2020.

But that coincided with a nosedive in ridership because of the coronavirus pandemic, with total annual ridership in 2024 at about 1.2 billion ‚Äî compared to roughly 1.7 billion each year before COVID, according to data.

Lieber on Friday argued the subway system bounced back quickly from Thursday‚Äôs torrential rainfall, noting all lines were back in service the next morning.

He said the electrical issues at West Fourth Street will be addressed by the recent capital plan.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre talking about 100-year-old electrical infrastructure, cloth-covered wires that are from our great-grandparents era that nobody went to update, and we just can‚Äôt live with that anymore,‚Äù he said.

In 2020, only 60% of substations were in a state of good repair.

But despite spending a massive $2.6 billion¬†from 2020 to 2024¬†to improve electrical infrastructure, that number only improved to 64% of substations being in a state of good repair.

Substations during that period appeared to be deteriorating faster than MTA crews could fix them.

The widespread transit woes ‚Äî including yet more flooding in the subways ‚Äî this week only highlighted the mixed results from the MTA‚Äôs spending.

But Lieber was quick to note that the MTA‚Äôs measures of subway and commuter train rider satisfaction have greatly increased this year.

‚ÄúCustomer satisfaction with subways is up 8%, Long Island Rail Road is up is up 5%, Metro-North is up 4%,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúCustomers before this week ‚Äî and you know, this week has definitely taken a hit on customer satisfaction ‚Äî are recognizing the improvements that have taken place. We have to get them back to that level of comfort.‚Äù

Not everyone was buying it.

‚ÄúNew Yorkers pay a dizzying number of taxes and fees towards the MTA and, yet, they can‚Äôt even keep the power on,‚Äù said state Sen. Jim Skoufis (D-Orange).

‚ÄúUntil their leadership brings radical reform to the system ‚Äì and stops depending on annual bailouts from Albany ‚Äì taxpayers will continue getting ripped off and riders will continue to be let down with substandard transit.‚Äù

Rep. Nicole Malliotakis (R-Staten Island) highlighted the issues by posting a clip showing straphangers climbing on subway gates to avoid flooding.

‚ÄúPathetic!‚Äù she wrote.
item.author: Matthew Fischetti, Vaughn Golden, Khristina Narizhnaya, Matt Troutman

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÁÜüÈ£üÂ∫óÂ∑•‰∫∫Âú®Êó†Á´ØË¢≠Âáª‰∏≠Ë¢´‚ÄúÊøÄÂä®‚ÄùÁöÑÁñØÂ≠êÂà∫Ê≠ªÔºöÊ∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫ê
item.description:
A Brooklyn deli worker was stabbed to death by an ‚Äúagitated‚Äù maniac in an unprovoked attack Friday afternoon, cops and sources said.¬†

The disturbed attacker walked into the¬†NY Deli & Mini Market Corp. on Hegeman Avenue near Van Siclen Avenue in East New York just after 3 p.m., and workers ‚Äî including the victim ‚Äî asked him to leave, law enforcement sources said.¬†

But he¬†came back a¬†few minutes later and tried to make his way behind the¬†counter,¬†the sources said.¬†

Employees again tried to stop him,¬†but he pulled out a knife and stabbed one of them,¬†believed to be in his 30s,¬†‚Äúa few times‚Äù in his torso,¬†according to the sources.¬†

The gravely wounded worker was rushed to Brookdale University Hospital Medical Center, where he¬†ultimately¬†succumbed to his injuries,¬†cops said.¬†

The unhinged knifeman fled the¬†scene and had not been caught hours later.

He is described as having a dark complexion and braided hair, standing about 5-foot-10 and weighing 190 pounds, police said.¬†
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.title: 23Â≤ÅÁöÑÁî∑Â≠©Âú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë°óÂ§¥Ë¢´ÂâçÂ•≥ÂèãÁöÑÊñ∞ÊÅãÊÉÖ‰∏âËßíÂÜ≤Á™ÅËá¥ÂëΩÂú∞Á¢æËøáÔºöË≠¶ÂØü
item.description:
A 23-year-old man ‚Äì who may have been armed with a gun ‚Äì was fatally run over by his ex-girlfriend‚Äôs new boyfriend in a love triangle clash in the middle of a Queens street Thursday night, cops said.

Shaivar Sonalall, 23, followed his ex ‚Äì who was riding in a car with her 31-year-old new beau behind the wheel ‚Äì to 101st Street and Liberty Boulevard in Ozone Park around 10:40 p.m., authorities and sources said.

Sonalall approached the driver‚Äôs side window and flashed what appeared to be a gun ‚Äì startling the motorist to the point that he drove off, striking the menace, police said.

Someone called 911, and officers found Sonalall lying in the street with severe body trauma, cops said.

He was rushed to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, where he succumbed to his injuries, police said.

The driver was initially taken into custody at the scene ‚Äì but the Queens District Attorney‚Äôs Office opted not to charge him because he feared for his life when he struck Sonalall, cops and sources said.
item.author: Joe Marino, Amanda Woods

item.title: ‰∏àÂ§´‰πãÈó¥ÁöÑÊåÅÂàÄÊñóÊÆ¥ÂØºËá¥34Â≤ÅÁî∑Â≠êÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÂÖ¨ÂØìÊ≠ª‰∫°
item.description:
A 34-year-old man was fatally stabbed during an early Friday clash with his husband in a Harlem apartment, authorities and sources said.

The man got into a knife fight with his 40-year-old husband inside the home on West 138th Street near Frederick Douglass Boulevard, neighboring the Victory Tabernacle Seventh Day Christian Church, law-enforcement sources said.

He was found dead in the bathroom with multiple stab wounds to his legs, the sources said.

The man‚Äôs husband claimed to cops that he had fallen asleep after their domestic clash, and woke up around 4 a.m. to find his beau lifeless on the toilet, according to sources.

EMS workers pronounced the man dead, and his husband was taken into custody. He was not immediately facing charges, the sources said.

Multiple knives were recovered at the scene, according to the sources.
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.title: ÁñØÁãÇÁöÑShane TamuraÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏Ç‰∏≠ÂøÉÂ§ßÂ±†ÊùÄ‰∏≠Âñ∑Ê¥í‰∫ÜËøë50ÂèëÂ≠êÂºπÔºåÈÄ†Êàê4‰∫∫Ê≠ª‰∫°ÔºöË≠¶ÂØü
item.description:
Maniac Shane Tamura sprayed nearly 50 bullets during his Midtown massacre ‚Äî as he shot dead four people, including an NYPD officer, according to police and sources.

The deranged gunman sprayed most of the bullets across Rudin Management‚Äôs 33rd-story offices at 345 Park Ave. ‚Äî which he entered after mistakenly getting off on the wrong floor during his search for the NFL headquarters, authorities said.

Cops recovered 24 discharged shell casings and 15 bullet fragments on that floor, which is where Tamura gunned down 27-year-old Julia Hyman, an associate at the real estate company, before turning the weapon on himself, according to cops‚Äô initial investigation.

Another 23 casings and 13 bullet fragments were found in the lobby and the ground floor of the skyscraper where Tamura, 27, unleashed his Monday rampage, authorities said.

Police found more than 800 unspent 357 Magnum Rounds sitting in the black BMW that Tamura was seen exiting while brazenly carrying an M4 rifle just before storming into the Park Avenue building, according to cops.

The crazed gunman immediately delivered a fatal shot at NYPD hero¬†Didarul Islam, who was working an extra shift on a security detail, upon entering around 6:30 p.m., then killing 43-year-old Blackstone executive Wesley LePatner as she hid behind a lobby column and building security guard and father Aland Etienne. who was at his desk.

Tamura then took the elevator ‚Äî shockingly allowing one woman to exit the lift unharmed ‚Äî and dialed up the violence after apparently realizing his plan to target the NFL fell apart, authorities said.

The madman left behind a suicide note revealing he targeted the sports organization because he believed he was suffering from chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) ‚Äî¬†despite not playing the sport past high school.

Tamura railed against the NFL in the three-page missive, which referred to Terry Long, the former Pittsburgh Steelers player who was diagnosed with CTE after downing antifreeze to kill himself 20 years ago.

‚ÄúPlease study brain for CTE. I‚Äôm sorry. The league knowingly concealed the dangers to our brains to maximize profits,‚Äù the note read.

‚ÄúThey failed us.‚Äù

The gunman had a history of mental health issues, and investigators found prescription medication for¬†depression and epilepsy in his Las Vegas home, authorities said.

Also found in the home was a note in which Tamura revealed he felt like a¬†‚Äúcomplete disappointment‚Äù¬†to his parents, including his retired cop father, sources said.
item.author: Amanda Woods, Katherine Donlevy

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇË†ïÂèòÊ∂âÂ´åÈÖ∑ÂàëÔºåÈ¶ñÊ¨°Ë∞ãÊùÄÂ•≥ÂèãÔºåÁã©Áåé‰ªçÂú®ÁªßÁª≠
item.description:
The hulking Bronx brute accused of torturing and murdering his 21-year-old girlfriend ‚Äî leaving her lifeless body in a stairwell ‚Äî was pictured for the first time as cops continue to hunt for him more than a week later.

Video released by the NYPD Thursday night shows the bearded Robert Strother, 27 ‚Äì who is wanted in connection to the July 22 murder of Princesa Encarnacion-Soto ‚Äì pounding the pavement with his hand tucked into the pocket of his red sweatpants, wearing a red baseball cap turned sideways.

Strother, described as standing about 6-foot-2 and weighing 245 pounds, was also last seen wearing a black and red sweater, and white and gray sneakers.

Police could not confirm where or when the video was taken.

Encarnacion-Soto was found unconscious and unresponsive just before 3 p.m. in the third-floor stairwell of the Fordham Heights building on Grand Concourse near East 183rd Street, where she had been staying with Strother and his mom, 54-year-old Naida Jorge, cops said at the time.

The severely battered and barely breathing 21-year-old was rushed to BronxCare Health System, where she was pronounced dead.

Cops followed a trail of blood that led into the Grand Concourse apartment where Strother is alleged to have tormented the young woman.

Encarnacion-Soto was tied up, stabbed from head to toe, and possibly beaten with a hammer before she was dumped in the stairwell, police and law enforcement sources said.

‚ÄúWe believe that she was tied down to the bed based on the blood that was on the bed,‚Äù NYPD Chief of Detectives Joseph Kenny said of the heinous abuse. ‚ÄúThe wounds themselves were inflicted for pain, not to kill. There are slice marks on her thighs, slice marks on her upper arms and shoulders.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe ones on her legs were fresh,‚Äù the chief added. ‚ÄúThe ones on her upper torso seemed like they were in the process of healing.‚Äù

Investigators also determined that Strother‚Äôs mother, Jorge, scrubbed the crime scene after the murder ‚Äì and she was arrested on charges of murder, manslaughter, hindering prosecution, concealment of a human corpse, police said.

‚ÄúShe did attempt to clean up the crime scene,‚Äù Kenny said. ‚ÄúThere was no blood on [the victim] while she laid on the staircase, and she was in fresh clothing that had no blood on her.‚Äù

Judge Harold Bahr ordered Jorge held without bail during her arraignment last Friday in Bronx Criminal Court.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs alleged to have assisted her son in trying to cover up a murder scene,‚Äù indicating an attempt to avoid prosecution, Bahr noted.

Her lawyer, Jason Gazewood, argued Jorge ‚Äúhas been a law-abiding citizen for the entirety of her life‚Äù as he sought for her to be released on supervision with electronic monitoring.

Gazewood also argued that court filings don‚Äôt provide many details about Jorge‚Äôs alleged actions in the case, and do not connect her to the brutal injuries inflicted on the victim.

‚ÄúIt looks like this is a case where this is not someone who is culpable for a murder charge,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt looks more like activities post to whatever happened to this person.‚Äù

She will next appear in court on August 18.
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.title: ÈïøÊúüÊâøËØ∫ÁöÑÂ∏ÉÈ≤ÅÂÖãÊûó‚ÄîÁöáÂêéÂå∫ÈìÅË∑ØÁªà‰∫éÂêëÂâçËøàËøõ‚Äî‰ΩÜË¶ÅÂà∞2030Âπ¥‰ª£ÊâçËÉΩÂÆåÊàê
item.description:
It‚Äôs finally getting on track.

The long-awaited light rail connection between Brooklyn and Queens has now moved into active development, Gov. Kathy Hochul announced Friday ‚Äî but the project won‚Äôt be complete until at least the 2030s.

Hochul, during an event along the abandoned rail line that will become the Interborough Express, or IBX, celebrated the MTA‚Äôs board this week advancing the expected $5.5 billion project into its design phase.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre turning these old tracks into something remarkable,‚Äù she crowed. ‚ÄúA clean, fast, 14-mile light rail line ‚Äì a connection between Brooklyn and Queens like never before.‚Äù

She also highlighted estimates that an end-to-end trip along the line will only be 32 minutes.

‚ÄúRiders will save 30 minutes each way. If you‚Äôre a round-trip commuter, guess what? That‚Äôs an hour back in your life.‚Äù

Proposals to build a Brooklyn-Queens rail service have percolated for nearly three decades, but only seriously advanced when Hochul announced in 2022 that an underused freight line would be converted into the Interborough Express.

The planned line would create 19 stations, connect 17 subway lines, 50 bus routes and two Long Island Rail Road hubs along its track from Sunset Park, Brooklyn to Jackson Heights, Queens, officials envision.

The IBX would also be the Big Apple‚Äôs first light rail line, as well the first end-to-end rapid transit built entirely in the city since the line that became the G train opened in 1937, officials said.

Drone footage and photos released by MTA officials Friday give a bird‚Äôs-eye view of the proposed route, including the LIRR-owned Bay Ridge Branch and the CSX-owned rail line Fremont Secondary.

The route winds through tree-lined, largely forgotten rail beds in both boroughs, with several bridges and tunnels that could present design difficulties, officials said.

But beyond broad strokes and a $2.75 billion commitment so far by Hochul, no serious engineering and design work had been done on the project ‚Äì until MTA board members Wednesday selected Jacobs and HDR to be design and engineering team, with a $166 million contract.

‚ÄúThanks to $166 million dollar state investment, that means a lot of planning is going to occur ‚Äì looking at the stations, tracks, vehicles signals ‚Äì so we can get shovels in the ground and make this become a reality,‚Äù Hochul said.

The design phase will be the last before construction begins, officials said.

The project is expected to be completed in the 2030s.

Hochul promised that whenever it‚Äôs finished that New Yorkers will have fewer travel hassles flitting between Brooklyn and Queens.

‚ÄúThe outer boroughs are now joined so that there‚Äôs not a requirement that if you want to go see your mother in Queens from Brooklyn that you won‚Äôt have to go into Manhattan first,‚Äù she said.
item.author: Matthew Fischetti, Matt Troutman

item.title: Âèç‰ª•Ëâ≤ÂàóÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂ•≥ËÆÆÂëòËíÇËäôÂ∞º¬∑Âç°Áè≠Ôºà Tiffany Caban Ôºâ ÔºåÊï∞ÂçÅÂêçÊäóËÆÆËÄÖËúÇÊã•ËÄåËá≥Êü•ÂÖã¬∑ËàíÈªòÔºà Chuck Schumer Ôºâ„ÄÅÂÖãÂ∞îÊñØÊªï¬∑ÂêâÂà©Â∏ÉÂÖ∞Âæ∑Ôºà Kirsten Gillibrand ÔºâÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂäûÂÖ¨ÂÆ§Ôºå
item.description:
Anti-Israel New York City Councilwoman Tiffany Caban was among those arrested as scores of screaming protesters descended on the Manhattan offices of Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand on Friday, sources told The Post.

Caban joined pro-Palestinian activists from Jewish Voices for Peace to occupy the Midtown office building, wearing T-shirts with ‚ÄúLet Gaza live‚Äù emblazoned across them.

Several protesters could be seen being zip-tied and led away as cops forced them out of the building, footage shot by Fox News showed.

It wasn‚Äôt immediately clear how many arrests were made.
item.author: Joe Marino, Emily Crane

item.title: BodegasÊòØÊñ∞ÁöÑ‚ÄúIt‚ÄùÈ§êÂéÖÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Â§ñÂá∫Â∞±È§êÁöÑÊàêÊú¨Ëû∫Êóã‰∏äÂçáÔºö ‚ÄúËøô‰∏ç‰ªÖ‰ªÖÊòØÈ©¨ËãèÈáåÊãâÂ•∂ÈÖ™Ê£í‰∫Ü‚Äù
item.description:
NYC‚Äôs corner markets are cornering the market ‚Äî¬†on haute cuisine.

As the cost of dining out in the Big Apple spirals higher, eating well without breaking the bank could be as simple as visiting your nearest bodega.

The city‚Äôs humble bazaars are increasingly perceived as epicurean pioneers ‚Äî¬†with gourmands and social media influencers clamoring for a bite.

The craze comes as the price of eating out in the five boroughs has been said to soar by nearly 30%, according to a 2024 City Comptroller‚Äôs Office report ‚Äî with even a sad Midtown desk lunch of salad or fast food often costing a minimum of $15 nowadays.

By contrast, determined diners willing to look past the toilet paper rolls and bricks of Cafe Bustelo can fill their belly at a wave of unlikely grocery gastro-hubs for a fraction of the price ‚Äî¬†without degrading their palate.

‚ÄúI go to my bodega every day, and the halal food is better than the food truck next door and cheaper ‚Äî¬†and they can do it all,‚Äù Karissa Dumbacher, an NYC foodfluencer with over 5 million followers across TikTok and Instagram, told The Post. ‚ÄúI mean, it‚Äôs not just mozzarella sticks anymore.‚Äù

Here‚Äôs the dish on six tasty, cutting-edge supping spots.

Java, no jive

There‚Äôs no menu at IndoJava, a bite-sized bodega in Elmhurst, Queens ‚Äî¬†but behind the selection of sambals and other Indonesian staples, intrepid diners will find one of the toughest tables in town.

Javanese chef Anastasia Dewi Tjahjadi, one of two haute-hash slingers (Thursdays, a chef from Jakarta takes over the stove), recently served just one dish: lontong mie ($15), a fragrant specialty from her hometown of Surabaya.

The piquant combo of noodles, bean curd, bean cake wedges, compressed rice cakes, garlic crackers, prawns and clam skewers packed a punch ‚Äî in a brawny broth infused with pungent shrimp paste and served with weapons-grade chili peppers.

And don‚Äôt bother asking the chef to turn the heat down.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want the people to come here and be, like, ‚ÄòOh, I‚Äôm sorry, I don‚Äôt like spicy‚Äô ‚Äî because my food ‚Ä¶ is spicy,‚Äù the griddle gourmet proudly told The Post. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt make it not spicy.‚Äù

Opened back in 2008, IndoJava has become a bona fide sensation. In a viral video, influencer Dumbacher labeled the offerings the closest thing to ‚Äúactual authentic Indonesian food in New York City.‚Äù

IndoJava‚Äôs food pop-ups are available on Tuesdays from 10 a.m.-8 p.m. and Thursdays from 10 a.m.-3 p.m. while supplies last; daily specials are announced on Instagram.

‚ÄúWe do very traditional, very authentic,‚Äù owner Elvi Goliat told The Post. ‚ÄúWe need to make something interesting so they will come every week.‚Äù

IndoJava, 85-12 Queens Blvd., Elmhurst

Mart of the deal

In Sunset Park, Brooklyn, the tiny Karen Deli has an ace up its sleeve ‚Äî¬†a speakeasy-like Guatemalan canteen located incongruously at the back, near a Central American mural.

The crown jewel drawing in-the-know types is the Pepian de Pollo ($13), a rich, spice-inflected stew studded with pumpkin seeds, best paired with a chuchito ($3), a miniature Guatemalan tamale, and washed down with a regional soda from the cooler.

This hearty combo costs a fraction of what you‚Äôd pay for one entr√©e at a sit-down spot in nearby trendy neighborhoods.

According to legendary NYC restaurant critic Robert Sietsema, unexpected finds like these show how bodegas are evolving.

‚ÄúFor decades, [the bodega] was a province of Puerto Ricans and Dominicans and African Americans, hence the term bodega, which is just Spanish for store,‚Äù the Village Voice alum told The Post.

‚ÄúThis is indicative of other groups taking over the bodegas, having a much broader selection,‚Äù he said.

Karen Deli, 6116 Fifth Ave., Brooklyn

Prawn stars

Jackson Heights, Queens, has always been the Big Apple‚Äôs multicultural bouillabaisse.

Head to Roosevelt Avenue ‚Äî where diners will find an Indian mini mart in the front and a Mexican seafood restaurant in the back.

Dubbed La Esquina Del Camaron Mexicano, the tiny, cash-only sit-down serves shrimp and octopus cocktails with cilantro, avocado and a ‚Äúsecret‚Äù cocktail sauce ($15 for a small portion).

It‚Äôs perhaps one of the few places in town you‚Äôd want to tuck into a plate of shellfish while pondering a wall of e-cigarettes and playing your scratch-off tickets.

La Esquina Del Camaron Mexicano, 80-02 Roosevelt Ave.

The hero we deserve

Sunny & Annie‚Äôs Deli in Manhattan‚Äôs East Village is much more than a bacon-egg-and-cheese broker, offering a 24-hour smorgasbord of inventive, submarine-sized, Asian-inflected heroes, which the Korean owners list on handscrawled notecards.

Wacky fare includes the Obama (grilled chicken and eggplant), the Bernie Sanders (teriyaki chicken and shiitake mushrooms) and other sandwiches whose ingredients appear to be charmingly unrelated to their celeb namesake.

Check out the Pho #1 ($10.99 cash, $11.97 using a card), which, like its eponymous soup, features beef, bean sprouts, basil, cilantro, sriracha and a slathering of hoisin.

The dining depot is a standby for food critic Sietsema, who described the noshes as ‚Äújust plain weird in a good sort of way.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no place that makes sandwiches that uses the odd combination of semi-healthy ingredients with good bread,‚Äù the pro told The Post. ‚ÄúAnd people that go in there for the first time, they‚Äôre dumbstruck by the menu.‚Äù

Sunny & Annie‚Äôs Deli, 94 Avenue B

Way to plant

Bodegas haven‚Äôt historically been bastions of vegetarian-friendly fare. Plantega is changing that ‚Äî¬†offering a ‚Äú100% plant-based menu‚Äù that ‚Äúreimagines New York‚Äôs iconic deli sandwiches,‚Äù ranging from the steak, egg and cheese burrito to the chopped cheese (both $12).

‚ÄúIn a way, bodegas are the city‚Äôs original test kitchens,‚Äù Plantega Founder and CEO Nil Zacharias told The Post.

The concept, launched in 2022, is available at 50 bodegas. It reflects the corner store‚Äôs legacy for innovation, where a ‚ÄúDominican-owned grill meets halal ingredients, or a classic bacon, egg and cheese gets a twist that reflects the neighborhood,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúToo often, ‚Äòbetter food‚Äô is framed as something exclusive,‚Äù he told The Post of grub which is often ‚Äúpackaged for a certain demographic.‚Äù

‚ÄúInstead of asking people to change their habits, we chose to meet them where they already eat,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúThat meant starting with the bodega, one of the most trusted, culturally rooted spaces in New York City.‚Äù

Plantega features a Chopped Cheese with Beyond Meat, Stockheld cultured cheddar and Fabalish vegan mayo ‚Äî‚Äì a combo that‚Äôs tasty and healthier than oft-dubious deli protein.

‚ÄúThe food is hot, satisfying and made to order, just without the meat sweats or the 3 p.m. crash that makes you question your life choices,‚Äù Zacharias quipped.

Plantega, various locations

Ock-ed and loaded

Probably the only bodega in remote Red Hook, Brooklyn, to have lured celebs like Ed Sheeran and Giants quarterback Eli Manning, Rahim Mohamed‚Äôs Red Hook Food Corp has become a viral sensation.

Better known online as General Ock ‚Äî derived from Americanized Arabic slang for ‚Äúakhi,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúbrother‚Äù ‚Äî the savvy seller has created a cutting-edge meal mecca, amassing over 5.5 million TikTok followers by sharing videos of him whipping up some of NYC‚Äôs wildest vittles.

And no ingredient is too outlandish.

Here, chopped cheese sandwiches are piled high with Pop-Tarts, mozzarella sticks, cotton candy, Rice Krispies Treats and more ‚Äî¬†in a method dubbed the Ocky Way.

‚ÄúFor years, I [saw] people get the same sandwiches and order all of these things on the side. I thought, ‚ÄòWhy can‚Äôt I mix it all together?‚Äô‚Äù he told The Post in 2021.

Red Hook Food Corp, 603 Clinton St., Brooklyn
item.author: Ben Cost

item.title: 9/11ÈÄÄ‰ºçÂÜõ‰∫∫Â£∞Áß∞FDNYÊ¨∫È™ó‰∫Ü‰ªñÁöÑÁ¶èÂà©ÂíåÂÖªËÄÅÈáë‚Äî‰ΩÜÊ∂àÈò≤ÈÉ®Èó®ËØ¥‰ªñÊ¨†‰ªñ‰ª¨60‰∏áÁæéÂÖÉ
item.description:
The FDNY is denying a decorated Army veteran and former fire marshal ‚Äî who bravely served in Iraq and Afghanistan after 9/11 ‚Äî¬† his benefits and pension, he claims in a scathing new lawsuit.

Leonard Draves, who toiled at Ground Zero to identify the remains of 343 fallen firefighters before being called to active US Army duty, alleges the FDNY is violating federal law protecting veterans, according to his $2 million suit.

‚ÄúIt was a very traumatic experience for me to go through that and be treated in such a horrible manner,‚Äù Draves, 64, said in an interview with The Post this week.

While on the battlefield, the city mailed Draves a letter nixing his health insurance and pension ‚Äî with two uniformed officials knocking on the door of his Queens home, terrifying his wife, he said.

‚ÄúMy wife ‚Äî she thought it was a death notification ‚Äî she was very distraught after that,‚Äù Draves said. ‚ÄúI was away serving and they‚Äôre harassing my family. I don‚Äôt understand why.‚Äù

Draves, who served in Afghanistan and Iraq from 2002 until 2019, argues he has the right to get his old job back under a US law that guarantees wartime soldiers their civilian jobs and benefits once discharged.¬†

But ‚Äúthey wouldn‚Äôt rehire me,‚Äù he said of the FDNY ‚Äî adding that he is also being denied access to a critical 9/11 health program.

His suit, filed in Brooklyn federal court last month, accuses the fire department of ‚Äúdiscriminatory conduct‚Äù that ‚Äúwas willful, wanton, and malicious, and showed reckless disregard for [Draves‚Äô] protected rights.‚Äù

Draves seeks to collect damages for lost pay and benefits in violation of a law called Uniformed Services Employment and Re-employment Rights Act ‚Äî or USERRA ‚Äî and to be allowed to participate in the World Trade Medical Monitoring Program.

But an FDNY spokesperson said its actually Draves who owes the city $600,000 in salary payback.

The spokesperson, who said the FDNY was reviewing the suit, claimed Draves collected two salaries while serving and never properly communicated that he enlisted full-time with the Army.

His attorney, Peter Gleason, hit back that as a commissioned officer, Draves did not enlist but had ‚Äúan obligation to serve at the will of the US Army.‚Äù

Gleason also noted that the Bloomberg-era payback deal ‚Äî where 9/11-era reservists who collected both city and military salaries had to repay the lesser of the two when decommissioned ‚Äî has a six-year statue of limitations.

‚ÄúAfter multiple combat tours Lt. Col. Draves attempted to return to his civilian employment with the FDNY only to have the door slammed in his face,‚Äù said Gleason, himself a veteran of the fire department.

‚ÄúTo suggest that LTC Graves should have shirked his military obligation to pacify FDNY bureaucrats flies in the face of the FDNY mantra, ‚ÄòNever leave a brother behind,'‚Äù said Gleason.

And while the USSERA typically has a five-year limit, that restriction is ignored during call-ups in a time of war or national emergency, he noted.

Draves grew up in Whitestone and attended both high school and the Transit Police Academy with Mayor Eric Adams. He worked as a transit cop for two years and joined the FDNY in 1985, getting promoted to fire marshal in 1999 ‚Äî all the while remaining in the Army reserves as a lieutenant colonel.¬†

He worked to identify the remains of the fallen firefighters and the one fire marshal lost on Sept. 11, 2001‚Äî a traumatic task that involved removing the bodies of his fallen brothers from their bunker gear, taking fingerprints and recovering remains and any personal artifacts.

Despite wearing industrial Tyvek suits, Draves said he came home every night covered with ‚Äúthe stench of death.‚Äù¬†

‚ÄúIt was a very, very tough time,‚Äù he said.

In February 2002, he got the call up to serve with the Army reserves ‚Äî so he filled out the proper paperwork with the FDNY and shipped out, according to his lawsuit, first to Afghanistan, then to Iraq where he trained local police to handle deadly IEDs that were killing scores of allies.

‚ÄúGetting called out to defend the country after 9/11, it was an honor,‚Äù Draves said.

With a shortage of commissioned officers, Draves said he was recalled to the regular Army, extending his service until he was discharged.

But while he was dodging Taliban bullets, the FDNY was getting ready to fire a salvo of their own, his lawsuit claims.

In 2010, shortly after his recall, Draves got a letter from the city saying he and his family were getting booted from their health insurance and the FDNY pension system, the suit states.

At the same time in Queens, a pair of uniformed city officials ‚Äúbanged‚Äù on the doors of the family home in an apparent attempt to locate him ‚Äî terrifying his wife and four kids, Draves claims.¬†

His family had to ‚Äúscramble‚Äù to get on a military insurance plan, said Draves.¬†

‚ÄúMy family suffered,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt was painful, and it did distract me from the mission.‚Äù

After his honorable discharge in 2019, Draves went for his medical review to re-enter the FDNY at the MetroTech Medical Center.

But in the middle of his physical, Draves said, he was kicked to the curb when the fire chief of the medical center told him he‚Äôd been gone too long, and he ‚Äúhad to leave.‚Äù

A promised follow-up never happened ‚Äî a ‚Äúconstructive termination,‚Äù the lawsuit claims.

Draves is still denied access to the FDNY‚Äôs WTC Health Program for his 9/11-related illnesses as a certified first-responder, the suit states.

Due to the ordeal and alleged mistreatment, Draves said, ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt bear going back‚Äù to the fire department.

‚ÄúThank God for the VA (Veterans Affairs) ‚Äî they really got me through this,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey take care of their brothers.‚Äù
item.author: Peter Senzamici

item.title: ËßÜÈ¢ëÊòæÁ§∫ÔºåÂ∏ÉÈ≤ÅÂÖãÊûó‰∫∫Â≠îÂèëÁîüÁÅ´ÁÅæÔºåË°å‰∫∫Â•îË∑ë
item.description:
Shocking video shows a huge column of fire bursting up in a busy Brooklyn intersection as a manhole exploded high in the air ‚Äî one of two in the borough in a matter of hours.

Video posted on Citizen shows several cars driving through Bushwick at 5:20 p.m. Thursday when flames shot up just as a firefighter was moving a barrier, leaving pedestrians sprinting for safety.

Con Ed responded to the scene ‚Äî near Central and Myrtle Avenues ‚Äî but thankfully there were no injuries, the FDNY said.

But just over two hours later another manhole fire erupted less than a mile away, with 60 fire and EMS personnel rushing to the scene at Lewis Ave and Pulaski Street, according to FDNY.

Another clip on Citizen shows flames ripping out of a manhole and spreading to other parts of the street before responders put it out.¬†

The blaze got dangerously close to vehicles and businesses, video shows.

Con Ed also responded to that manhole fire and no injuries were reported, FDNY said.
item.author: Patrick Reilly
